title: Verified Purchase

post_time: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2024

title: Not helpful for me
content: I was truly shocked by the amount of misinformation presented by Mel. She is constantly stating fear begins in the body. This is completely false. I took time to try to find anything corroborating her claims, but everything I found was clear that fear begins in the brain, specifically the amygdala. After registering something that it feels may be dangerous, it sends a fear signal to your body. The fear is then analyzed by other areas of the brain to decide if the fear response is necessary. I had hoped that Mel was just stating her point poorly, but that just isn't the case. She flat out tells one of the clients that she's "coaching" that fear isn't an intellectual problem, it's a physical problem. I honestly don't know how she could come to that conclusion. She repeatedly states that fear lives in the body, and that the body remembers fear from childhood. She bases this on what seems to be her misunderstanding of a study where people showed a physical response to a situation before they were consciously aware of it. What the study showed was that your subconscious mind is aware of threats and danger long before your conscious mind is. But Mel concluded that it meant your body is aware of threats and danger before your brain is.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on April 8, 2019

title: Verified Purchase
content: Now, about her "coaching." I doubt what she's doing would be acceptable by the International Coach Federation (ICF) as good coaching practice. She spends as much, if not more, time the clients speaking. She barely gets into their problems before she starts talking about her own similar problems, and then proceeds to tell them what they're REALLY feeling and thinking. One of her clients, the hoarder, was tell her what she felt her problems were and Mel would cut her off and tell her it was something else. Specifically, she felt she was a control freak, and Mel told her she was wrong. However, in the recap portion that takes place during the book recording Mel agrees that she was a control freak, but cuts out the portion where she told her she was wrong. Mel basically bullied this same client into cleaning out her house. When the client was resistant, she went so far as to get the client's boyfriend on the phone and they both pressured her into it. They really didn't take any time to get to the core of the issues that lead her to hoarding or really dealing with those issues. And that seemed to be the case for all of the clients. Mel really didn't dig down deeper into the real issues. She developed her own conclusions from the start and told them what to do, without giving them a chance to come up with their own conclusions and solutions. This is getting wordy already, but I could really write several paragraphs on each of the coaching sessions about the poor quality of coaching that was provided.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on September 14, 2020

title: learning so much from Mel and she is just cool
content: I was severely disappointed. I respect and admire Mel Robbins. I buy her products, I'm on her email list, I watch her shows and livestreams, & I've read her books. I expected much better from her. I feel that going forward I'll have to take everything she says with a grain of salt until I can verify it for myself.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on March 29, 2019

title: Misinformation Galore & Terrible "Coaching"
content: It's worth a listen if you're wanting to take control of your life more. Helpful tips and ways of looking at dysfunctions and (learned) character traits. But be aware that the people interviewed reveal perfectly within their 5-minute self descriptions what their core issues may be. And Robbins, who is not a doctor nor licensed therapist, based on limited 'patient' information is able to immediately diagnose issues and root causes and solutions.  In real life, people aren't so self aware, self descriptive, so easily revealing,  nor can an analyst or therapist conclude  within just minutes what is going on and what should be done.  So,  real self examination and professional therapy will take more time, more effort.  Robbins has compacted it all into pithy profiles, it feels a little manipulated and packaged.  Still, the presentations can be illustrative and helpful to many.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on June 7, 2019

title: Helpful, but Robbins' quickie psychoanalysis is bit deceptive
content: I RARELY ever review on Amazon, but this was necessary.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on November 6, 2019

title: Game Changer! ⭐
content: Searching through Audible for the next best listen is like finding the Chamber of Secrets. You either wind up back in the toilet with Moaning Myrtle, or you find the next Horcrux needed to defeat the Dark Lord, in this case the Dark Lord being boredom.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on February 28, 2019

title: Helpful in Some Ways - But How About People With Real Problems
content: I found some value in this audio book. I find Mel Robbins to be a very compelling thinker, and I like her no BS way of presenting her ideas. I had high hopes for this book. I actually preferred the content that was not part of the coaching sessions, because the first-world problems of the first two clients was a turn-off. I didn't make it to the third. For people looking for real help in getting control of their lives, the first two clients who have pretty nice lives but are questioning if they will ever do enough because a parent was grouchy and made them get As on their report card, is not terribly useful unless you're 25 with an advanced degree and watching Eat, Pray, Love left you more confused than ever.  Would love to see Mel Robbins do this again with real problems. People who have perhaps lost everything and starting over. Or people over 50. Or self-made people. So many great ideas in here, but just felt like her target audience was 30 year old upper middle class conflicted yoga moms.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on February 4, 2021

title: If you have trauma/PTSD - this is a must listen!
content: I honestly can’t fathom the one star reviews here. How insulting. This book was a tremendous inspiration to me. I related so intimately to each of the characters and I could’ve immediately started this book over as quickly as I finished it. I found so much truth and knowledge here! I absolutely adored this work and the stories of those involved and it truly connected some of the dots in my life that I had been feeling gaps in for so long. I’ve listened to all the big self help books but this work by Mel Robbins really bridged the gap for me!! Highly, highly recommend.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on July 7, 2020

title: One of the best books I have read in a long time
content: Y’all 1 star reviewers really need to take a good hard look at yourselves — walking away from this book without a single positive thing to say or claiming not to have any positive knowledge gained has everything to do with YOU..... check your ego.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2019

title: Really useful despite the naysayers and closed minded
content: Mel really nailed it with this book. She provides practical, actionable insights about how to identify limiting fears and quickly overcome them. I really enjoyed listening to Heather's session, in particular, in which Mel coached her through her struggles with perfectionism. The main takeaway was that what we really fear is losing our sense of control. The way to regain our control is to identify how fear presents itself in our bodies and then respond in a more empowered way. 5 stars! I also really like the fact that Mel provides an accompanying workbook to keep her readers accountable. Too many self-help books say the same things, and the advice isn't really actionable. This book is totally different and is one of the best books of any category I have read in a long time.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on July 29, 2019

title: Fantastic book with great insight
content: I started this book on my 90 minute drive home and found it so easy to listen to relative to some information dense books that I had myself believing that I got all there was to get out of it and could potentially even stop listening. However I kept going and it never ceased impressing me. I noted some things that she said that weren't 100% accurate but they did still succeed in steering you towards valid and useful concepts.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on September 8, 2021

title: A most listen audible.
content: I will preface this by saying that I love Mel Robbins. I happened upon her TedTalk about 6 months ago and watched it about once every other day until she started doing Coffee Talks on IG. I scoured for podcasts and videos with her and was dismayed that most were based on the 5 Second Rule (which doesn't work for me). I was thrilled when she had the MindSet Reset course at the beginning of the year and even more thrilled when this audible original became available shortly after that was over. I love this. Even when I can't relate to the stories or the people's problems there is still some lesson in there that I take with me.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on March 31, 2019

content: Mel Robbins is definitely my spirit guide through life and I am glad she is branching out past the 5 Second Rule and I can't wait to watch the talk show.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2019

title: Wow!
content: I'm still listening to this audiobook... I am giving 5 stars because I love Mel Robbins and I refuse to give her anything less than 5 stars. But I will admit this audiobook is hard to listen to mainly because the coaching sessions involve a lot of emotional crying and sniffles which makes it awkward to listen to when I'm driving to work. This audiobook is helpful and Mel offers amazing insight and tips but I will admit I could have done WITHOUT feeling like I was listening in on someone's private therapy session. I'm glad I listened to the coaching sessions because afterwards Mel reflects on important parts, replays them and gives her amazing invaluable insight/advice. This book is helping me reflect on a lot of things but I can only listen to so much of it every day due to the above mentioned issues.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on March 16, 2019

title: Mel Robbins = Crazy awesome
content: P.S if you are looking for a book with deep psychological research and study, this might not be for you. There so many negative reviews because people have the wrong expectations. title: It’s a great book for everyone $ I will definitely listen to it again and again
content: I'm a big fan, actually went to the 4th taping of her TV show.  If you read the 5 Second Rule - then you are familiar with Mel's style.  I prefer the audio version because her delivery is so down to earth & she is an excellent speaker.  I wish I was thrilled enough to give this 5 stars BUT although I found the interviews interesting , the "TAKE AWAYS" each of the many interviews wee just annoyingly TOO long and by the 3rd one, I was skipping over it.  I really didn't want to recap anymore of the interview.  My opinion is that her discussion with the client during the interview was sufficient rather than have to listen to repeats of some segments of the interviews .  I think much more editing would have been very appropriate for this book.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on March 5, 2020

title: In the therapy session the author therapist uses the F word constantly
content: I am so disappointed! When you buy a book that is supposed to help you emotionally, you want to believe that the therapist is professional.
